                    ### Question
                    Fosphenytoin different from phenytoin in which of the following-

                    ### Options

opb. Can be mixed with saline
opc. Can be given orally
opd. It is the drug of choice for myoclonic seizures

### Enhanced Information (For Contextual Support):
Fosphenytoin is a water-soluble prodrug of phenytoin, primarily used for the treatment of seizures. It differs from phenytoin in several key aspects: 1) Fosphenytoin can be mixed with saline, which is not the case for phenytoin, confirming the first option. 2) Fosphenytoin is not effective for absence seizures, aligning with the consensus that it is similar to phenytoin in this regard, thus the second option is incorrect. 3) Fosphenytoin is typically administered intravenously or intramuscularly and is not given orally, making the third option incorrect. 4) Fosphenytoin is not the drug of choice for myoclonic seizures, as other medications are preferred, confirming the fourth option is also incorrect. Therefore, the only correct distinction is that fosphenytoin can be mixed with saline.
